text: I assume that when you say most traded you mean most traded at a particular moment in time like when the race starts as this obviously has different interpretations at different times. Being most traded one hour before the off does not mean it will be most traded at the off or at the end of the race. Assuming you are using the start of the race as the reference point and assuming you want to bet before the start of the race, you will not know for certain that a horse will be most traded at your reference point. Then the most traded indicator itself is a random variable and you want to calculate `p(win|mt)p(mt)`

elements.text: I assume that when you say most traded you mean most traded at a particular moment in time like when the race starts as this obviously has different interpretations at different times. Assuming you are using the start of the race as the reference point and assuming you want to bet before the start of the race, you will not know for certain that a horse will be most traded at your reference point. Then the most traded indicator itself is a random variable and you want to calculate
p(win|mt)p(mt)

What is the hypothesis here? That traded volume can give you a clue as to whether a horse will come specifically first, or will generally rank towards 1st? If the latter, I'd probably first look at corr(x,y) where X is traded volume of a horse as a ratio of total volume traded in the market, and y is the finishing position as a ratio of total number of horses.

text:
Since our hypothesis is `P(win | mt)` , to use Bayes, we need to know first `P(mt | win)` but this is 0.98 since the event of a win does not change the fact that this horse was the most traded before the race starts.

So know we have:

`P(win) = 0.143`
`P(mt) = 0.98`
`P(mt | win) = 0.98`

With this in hand, we can use Bayes to calculate _*P(win | mt)*_

elements.text: Since our hypothesis is
P(win | mt)
, to use Bayes, we need to know first
P(mt | win)

but this is 0.98 since the event of a win does not change the fact that this horse was the most traded before the race starts.

So know we have:
P(mt | win) = 0.98
With this in hand, we can use Bayes to calculate
P(win | mt)

attachments.title: Naive Bayes classifier
attachments.text:
In statistics, Naive Bayes classifiers are a family of simple "probabilistic classifiers" based on applying Bayes' theorem with strong (naïve) independence assumptions between the features. They are among the simplest Bayesian network models, but coupled with Kernel density estimation, they can achieve higher accuracy levels.Naïve Bayes classifiers are highly scalable, requiring a number of parameters linear in the number of variables (features/predictors) in a learning problem. Maximum-likelihood training can be done by evaluating a closed-form expression, which takes linear time, rather than by expensive iterative approximation as used for many other types of classifiers.
In the statistics and computer science literature, naive Bayes models are known under a variety of names, including simple Bayes and independence Bayes. All these names reference the use of Bayes' theorem in the classifier's decision rule, but naïve Bayes is not (necessarily) a Bayesian method.
